Sand_War.Summary: The Sand War, part of the Arab Cold War and the broader Cold War context, was a brief but intense conflict between Morocco and Algeria over disputed border regions. Centering around the oasis towns of Tindouf and Figuig, the war resulted in a military stalemate with no territorial changes. The Organization of African Unity mediated the conflict, leading to a ceasefire and the establishment of a demilitarized zone.
Sand_War.Location: Around the oasis towns of Tindouf and Figuig
Sand_War.Result: Military stalemate with no territorial changes. The conflict led to the closing of the border south of Figuig, Morocco/Béni Ounif, Algeria. Morocco abandoned its attempts to control Béchar and Tindouf after OAU mediation. A demilitarized zone was established.
